noun.description: A literary device in narrative, in which a past event is narrated at a point later than its chronological place in a story.
examples: writers make strategic use of both analepsis and prolepsis in telling a story
the analepsis terminated the earthly ministry

origin: Mid 17th century (in the sense rhetorical device involving repetition of a word or phrase): via late Latin from Greek analēpsis, from ana up + lambanein take.
